title: The frustrations of young graduates who wear the hijab and struggle to find work in France
summary: Joining the French labor market remains a challenge for these women. Some turn to self-entrepreneurship, more welcoming companies, or even decide to work abroad.

title: Brazil's president stirs controversy by comparing war in Gaza to the Holocaust
summary: Invited to the African Union summit in Addis Ababa, Lula condemned the Israeli army's violence in Gaza and refused to blame Vladimir Putin's regime for the death of Russian opposition figure Alexei Navalny.

title: Macron aims to convince he's not 'pursuing a far-right policy' in interview to Communist newspaper
summary: Macron asserted in an interview with L'Humanité that he 'never considered' French far-right parties to be part of the 'republican arc,' and defended abolishing birthright citizenship in overseas Mayotte.

title: Von der Leyen's careful campaign for a second term as European Commission chief
summary: On Monday, the German EU Commission president was put forward for another five-year term by her German Christian Democratic Union party. However, after the June European elections, the road to re-election will be strewn with pitfalls.

title: South Korea's 'no-kids zones' reflect a society where people  have given up on trying to accommodate each other
summary: Hundreds of restaurants and cafés refusing entry to children have sprung up across the country, aimed largely at ensuring disturbance-free environments for grown-ups. But the phenomenon is part of a broader effort to ostracize various social groups.

title: Alice Milliat, Olympic Games pioneer, finally honored
summary: The French rower and swimmer fought to have the first women's Olympics held in 1922. With the Games coming to Paris, the tireless campaigner for gender equality in sport is back in the limelight.

title: Eiffel Tower closes as staff go on strike
summary: The strike, which was called to protest over the way the monument is managed financially, could be extended, according to unions.

title: Europeans prioritize defense against Russian threat at Munich Security Conference
summary: At the 60th security conference, European leaders, following France and Germany's lead, took a stronger stance against Moscow, stressing not only the need for more aid to Ukraine, but also to reinforce their own defense capabilities.

title: Diversity in Hollywood is declining: 'Recognizing racist stereotypes is not the same as fighting them!'
summary: Since 2008, the Annenberg Inclusion Initiative has been assessing the American film industry's efforts in terms of representation. The damning results of its latest study, published in January, challenge the claims made by the studios.

title: Andrew Scott embraces 'the lie that tells the truth' in 'All Of Us Strangers'
summary: Discovered thanks to TV shows 'Sherlock' and 'Fleabag,' the Irish actor is quietly establishing himself as one of the most interesting of his generation.

title: UN human rights chief slams UK's Rwanda asylum seeker plan
summary: The controversial plan by Rishi Sunak's government to deport those seeking asylum in the UK to Rwanda had already been criticized by the country's Supreme court, and by a joint parliamentary committee, as 'not compatible' with the UK's rights 'obligations.'

title: Israel-Hamas war: At Egyptian border, Israelis try to prevent humanitarian aid from reaching Gaza
summary: Convinced that 'up to 70% of these shipments are hijacked' by Hamas, these activists are attempting to slow down the trucks destined for the Palestinian enclave.

title: Israeli occupation of Palestine on trial at the ICJ
summary: The International Court of Justice will assess the legality of Israel's military governance in the West Bank and Gaza. Beginning February 19, representatives from 52 countries will present their arguments over one week to the judges of the UN's top court.

title: Arizona, the 'Silicon Desert' boosted by the semiconductor war
summary: Around Phoenix, giants like TSMC and Intel are investing billions of dollars setting up a huge industrial chip ecosystem. They are being spurred on by the federal government, which no longer wants to depend on Asia in this vital tech sector.

title: Why 2024 is key for France's national energy company
summary: France's EDF faces two challenges: the commissioning of the EPR nuclear reactor, 12 years behind schedule, and launching the construction of a new generation of reactors.

title: Navalny continues to embarrass Russian authorities, even in death
summary: The investigating committee has opened a 'verification procedure' which allows Russian authorities to keep the body for thirty days. No cause of death has yet been provided.

title: BAFTA 2024: 'Oppenheimer' wins seven prizes including best picture
summary: Christopher Nolan's atomic bomb epic dominated the 77th British Academy Film Awards while the dark comedy 'Poor Things' won five awards including Best Actress for Emma Stone.

title: Egypt builds security zone in Sinai anticipating influx of refugees from Gaza
summary: Construction machines are clearing an area in preparation for an Israeli offensive on Rafah, the last sanctuary in the Palestinian enclave.

title: Haiti: Murdered president's widow indicted in his killing
summary: The indictments of a total of 50 other suspects are expected to further destabilize the country as it struggles with a surge in gang violence and recovers from a spate of protests demanding the resignation of the current prime minister.

title: Israel-Hamas war: Fatah and the Islamist movement increase contacts in view of Palestinian reconciliation
summary: After several meetings between officials from both parties in Doha, where Hamas leaders reside in exile, Palestinian president Mahmud Abbas made the trip himself on February 11, 2024. At stake is the governance of Gaza and the West Bank as part of a potential comprehensive conflict resolution plan.

title: Paris 2024: Will public transport be ready on time for the Olympics?
summary: The initial offer of free, all-out transportation for the Olympic Games has gradually dwindled and become a source of tension, even concern, for the smooth running of the event and the state of public transport in the Paris region.

title: Australia plans to build the biggest navy since WWII
summary: Amid growing regional tensions with China, which have led Australia to join the Aukus and the Quad security cooperation groups, the country has outlined a $7 billion plan to more than double its existing warship fleet.

title: Eiffel Tower strike draws attention to its business model
summary: Two of the tower's workers' unions have denounced an 'untenable' business model, notably due to increasing sums paid to the Paris city hall, which will also lead to increased ticket prices for visitors.

title: Indian farmers to take food price protest to New Delhi
summary: Indian farmers have been protesting since mid-February, demanding laws fixing minimum prices for 23 crops, and will continue their demonstrations after rejecting a government offer, judged 'not in the interest of farmers.'

title: WikiLeaks founder Assange starts final UK legal battle to avoid extradition to US on spy charges
summary: The 52-year-old has been fighting extradition for more than a decade, including seven years in self-exile in the Ecuadorian Embassy in London and the last five years in a high-security prison.

title: Emmanuel Macron wants more frequent trips out of the media spotlight
summary: Since 2017, the president has sought to limit the access of journalists and now wishes to meet the French public 'away from the press.' The practice is unthinkable in other major democracies.

title: 'It's become more difficult to reach a consensus.' Why is Germany's social contract under threat?
summary: At the Daimler Truck plant in Gaggenau, the switch to electric vehicles is raising great concern among employees. The IG Metall union is trying to contain the frustration, a tinderbox for populism.

title: The European far right opportunistically supports farmers
summary: The European far right has embraced the farmers' movement by stirring up fears of the disappearance of farmers and food insecurity, less than four months before the European elections.

title: Putting an end to the persecution of Julian Assange
summary: The founder of WikiLeaks is seeking a last-ditch appeal in the British courts against his extradition to the US, where he is being prosecuted for espionage. Whatever the reader's opinion of him, we must hope for a sign of humanity from the British judges.

title: How Mayotte became the ideological laboratory of the French far right
summary: For several decades now, the advocates of radical immigration restrictions have been using this troubled French Indian Ocean department as a 'case study' to test the ideas they want to see disseminated in mainland France.

title: Migratory species: Countries commit to better protection for the Balkan lynx, the Pallas cat and the bull shark
summary: The 14th Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species ended with a series of commitments from countries to try to preserve these species, half of which are in decline.

title: 'With eight months to go before the US presidential election, announcing Donald Trump's victory is a lazy gamble'
summary: In the run-up to the November election, a healthy economy is likely to cause a turnaround in US opinion, writes columnist Arnaud Leparmentier.

title: UN food agency suspends aid to north Gaza after gunfire, looting
summary: The World Food Program has suspended aid deliveries to northern Gaza despite 'unprecedented levels of desperation' after it faced violence and chaos in the besieged enclave.

title: Polish farmers resume Ukraine border blockade over imports
summary: Ukraine's state railway company denounced the protesting farmers after they opened two Ukrainian freight cars and poured grain destined for Germany onto the tracks.
